conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the charged ball to find the electric field strength.
The small ball is in equilibrium, so the net force acting on it is zero.
Forces acting on the ball: gravitational force \( mg \), tension \( T \), and electric force \( qE \).
Components of forces must balance each other out due to equilibrium.
Define variables: \( \theta \), \( T \), \( m \), \( g \), \( q \), \( E \).
Resolve tension \( T \) into vertical component \( T \cos(\theta) \) and horizontal component \( T \sin(\theta) \).
Solve for \( T \) from vertical component: \( T = \frac{mg}{\cos(\theta)} \).
Substitute \( T \) into horizontal component equation: \( \frac{mg}{\cos(\theta)} \sin(\theta) = qE \).
The electric field strength \( E \) is \( \boxed{E = \frac{mg \tan(\theta)}{q}} \).
